Title: Pause New Water Rights Applications
Description: Suspend all new water rights applications in the Great Salt Lake basin, as implemented by Gov. Spencer Cox in November 2022.
Notes: Took figure 4000AF/5 years and withdrew that from total consumption

Title: Turf Conversion
Description: Replace turf grass with local plants that require less water.
Notes: Unsure about trustworthness of numbers. Taken for northern Utah

Title: Install Secondary Meters
Description: There are approximately a quarter million unmetered connections in Utah. Installing water meters on these connections would enable consumers to understand their water use. Water meters also allow water suppliers to charge by usage. House bill HB242 aims to install secondary meters.
Notes: Includes houses not in N Utah

Title: Limit Mineral Industry's Water Usage
Description: US Magnesium and other mineral producers draw water from the Great Salt Lake, which they then evaporate to extract minerals from.
Notes: Preventing the canal construction would only have an impact at lower lake levels

Title: Pipe Water Canals
Description: Canals carry water throughout and between fields. Installing water impermeable lining into a canal reduces the amount of water that seeps into the soil.

Title: Enable Water Banking
Description: Water banking allows water rights holders to lease their water to others without losing their rights . This policy simulates leasing water rights from farmers during wet years for the benefit of the lake.
Notes: $20/AF assumed. Only for Cache Valley. Paying to lease additional water may increase the number of farmers willing to sell additional water, because it would incentivize conservation. Averaged over 1990-2020.

Title: Buy Water Rights
Description: Purchase and hold water rights for the benefit of the lake. This slider estimates a flat price of $5,000 per acre foot, which is significantly higher then current prices. For more details, see below.

Title: Limit Hay Cultivation
Description: Alfalfa and other hays are consume 70% of  Utah's water, while generating a small portion of the states economic output. This policy simulates the state directly paying farmers to not grow hay.

Title: Replace Flood Irrigation with Sprinklers
Description: Flood irrigation is significantly less water efficient per acre then irrigating with sprinklers. Significant water can be saved by transitioning to sprinkler irrigation without effecting farmer productivity.

Title: Improve Irrigation Scheduling
Description: Studies show that improved irrigation scheduling can reduce water use by around 15%. This policy simulates investing in irrigation scheduling technologies.
Notes: This seems wrongï¿½. why does it cost so much? How does it save so much water?
